claims_to_validate.claim_text: Current system lacks automated salary calculation based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking of overtime and unpaid leaves.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings overrides the formula configured in leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is being superseded by payroll settings. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were calculated based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amount.

The system does not correctly account for 366 days in leap years when calculating end of service gratuity, resulting in incorrect service period and benefit calculations. When calculating for 2024 (a leap year), the system uses 365 days instead of 366 days, leading to a lower gratuity amount.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.
System gratuity calculation (AED 231,821) slightly differs from manual calculation (AED 252,485), but support confirmed system calculation is correct based on service duration and daily wage formula

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (specifically February 29th), causing minor discrepancies in total service days calculation. The system calculated 912 days, while manual calculation showed 913 days by including the leap day.
System calculates 623 days instead of 622 days when computing job tenure, potentially causing slight variations in gratuity calculation

System calculates leave salary using a fixed daily rate divisor (potentially 30 days) which may not accurately reflect calendar month variations. User expected calculation based on 31 days, but system used 30 days, resulting in a slight salary amount difference.
The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals across months

The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation mismatches. This is a system design limitation where leave salary and salary proration use independent daily wage formulas.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The daily wage calculator fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing. The system only correctly prorates salaries when departure dates are in the past.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes misaligned between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.
The system calculates daily wage using a custom divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations

The system displays incorrect number of days in remarks for February unpaid leave deduction. Remarks show 31 days instead of 29 days, despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct. This is a display bug in the remarks field where the wrong number of days is referenced.

The system uses a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions. The global setting calculates deductions using a method different from the configured policy (Basic Salary / Working Days).

The system displays the daily rate from the payroll processing month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate is inconsistent with the leave period.
Salary calculation is based on a fixed 26 working days per month standard (313 working days per year, excluding 52 weekly offs).
Payroll daily wage calculator configuration takes precedence over leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations.
Leave deduction calculations are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.
The system defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize leap years with 366 days in service period calculations.
Daily wage calculations for pro-rated amounts are consistently undercalculated by small decimal points (0.1 or 0.2) when computing End of Service settlements.
Leave days are only accrued at month-end, preventing prorated inclusion for mid-month departures
Unclear rules for counting service days, including whether the departure date is considered a working day and how leap year days are incorporated
Daily wage is always calculated using (Basic Salary / 30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas
Leave salary calculation is rigidly tied to predefined policy configurations, preventing easy customization for specific employee scenarios
Leave encashment can be calculated using 'working days' or 'custom days' settings, which directly impacts monthly accrual calculations
The platform calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations that cannot automatically align without manual configuration.
Daily wage proration is calculated based on the specific work week configuration, which may include all 7 days as working days
Salary proration only works correctly for departure dates in the past, not for future departure dates
When leave transactions are modified or deleted, the payroll deduction module does not automatically reconcile or remove associated deductions.
Daily wage is calculated as: (basic salary + allowance) / working days, where working days exclude weekends and public holidays specific to the employee's country of residence.
System uses 30.42 days as divisor for daily wage calculation, not standard calendar days
Daily wage calculations use calendar days, with specific handling required for months with varying days (especially February in leap years).
The platform has a global configuration that supersedes individual policy-level settings for unpaid leave calculations
Daily rate is calculated as (Basic + Allowances) / Working Days, excluding public holidays
